usa: Inauguration of Barack Obama: Obama was inaugurated the forty-fourth President of the United States.[40]
President Barack Obama signed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, a $787 billion economic stimulus package.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference">[41]</sup>

Tea Party protests: The first of a series of protests, focusing on smaller government, fiscal responsibility, individual freedoms and conservative views of the Constitution, were conducted across the country.[42]
Death of Michael Jackson: Pop icon Michael Jackson died.[43]
Sonia Sotomayor was sworn in as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court; becoming the first Latina Justice.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference">[44]</sup>
Fort Hood shooting: Nidal Malik Hasan killed twelve servicemen and injured thirty-one.[45]
india: India and Russia sign deals worth $700 million, according to which Moscow will supply Uranium to Delhi.
Trial of sole surviving suspect Ajmal Kasab in Mumbai attacks begins.
Resounding general election victory gives governing Congress-led alliance of PM Manmohan Singh an enhanced position in parliament, only 11 seats short of an absolute majority.
australia: Black Saturday bushfires: Massive bushfires swept across Victoria, resulting in 173 fatalities.<sup id="cite_ref-capped_2-0" class="reference">[2]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-deathtoll_3-0" class="reference">[3]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference">[4]</sup>
albania: Albania joins NATO and submit application for membership in the European Union

Sali Berisha's centre-right Democratic Party wins 2009 parliamentary elections by a narrow margin. Prior to the election, the electoral law was changed to a regional proportionally system.Berisha's alliance won enough seats to form a government, though it fell one seat short of a majority during the elections of Jun 28, 2009, having to join forces with a splinter socialist party, the Socialist Movement for Integration of Ilir Meta, whom Berisha appointed to the post of Deputy Prime Minister for Foreign Affairs, and later Minister of Economy, Trade and Energy. It is the first time since the start of multi-party democracy in 1991 that a ruling party has been forced into a coalition through not winning enough seats on its own.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference">[5]</sup>

Protests begin in Tirana, led by opposition Socialist Party leader Edi Rama, against allegedly rigged vote counting in the 2009 elections. Berisha has refused any recount of the votes, on the ground that the Albanian Constitution do not foresee such procedure. The political crisis between government and opposition has worsened over time, with the Socialists abandoning parliamentary debates for months and staging hungerstrikes to ask for internal and international support.
